title: The First Rule of ARIA ü•á
ques: What is the **"First Rule of ARIA"** as stated by the W3C?

answer.content:
**"If you can use a native HTML element or attribute with the semantics and behavior you require already built in, then do so instead of re-purposing an element and adding an ARIA role, state or property to it."**

Example: Use `<button>` instead of `<div role="button">`.

explanation: Native elements come with free accessibility (keyboard support, roles). ARIA is a bridge for when native elements fall short.

title: ARIA Roles üé≠
ques: You are building a custom alert box using a `<div>`. What ARIA `role` should you give it so screen readers announce it immediately?

answer.content:
`role="alert"`

This gives the element an implicit `aria-live="assertive"`, meaning screen readers will interrupt the current speech to read the alert message.

explanation: Roles define **what** an element is. Examples: `dialog`, `tablist`, `progressbar`.

title: ARIA Labels: Label vs. LabelledBy üè∑Ô∏è
ques: Compare `aria-label` and `aria-labelledby`. Which one is generally preferred if visible text is available?

answer.content:
*   **`aria-label`:** Takes a string string directly (e.g., `aria-label="Close"`). Use this if there is no visible text on screen.
*   **`aria-labelledby`:** Takes the **ID** of another element (e.g., `aria-labelledby="modal-title"`). Use this to point to existing visible text.

**Preferred:** `aria-labelledby` is better because it ensures the visible label matches the accessible name.

explanation: Duplicating text in `aria-label` creates maintenance issues. Linking to existing text is robust.

title: State Management with ARIA üö¶
ques: You have a custom accordion widget. Which ARIA attribute handles the **open/closed** state?

answer.content:
`aria-expanded="true"` or `aria-expanded="false"`.

You must update this attribute via JavaScript whenever the user toggles the accordion.

explanation: ARIA states inform the user of the current interaction status. Just hiding the content (`display: none`) isn't enough; you must tell the screen reader *that* it is effectively hidden.

title: Hidden Content üôà
ques: What is the difference between `aria-hidden="true"` and HTML's `hidden` attribute?

answer.content:
*   **`hidden` (HTML):** Removes the element from the layout visually AND from the accessibility tree. It is gone for everyone.
*   **`aria-hidden="true"`:** Removes the element from the accessibility tree (screen readers ignore it) but **keeps it visible** on screen. Use this for purely decorative icons.

explanation: Be careful with `aria-hidden`. You don't want to hide interactive content from screen reader users.
